awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Vicon system for multi-disciplinary research and education in rehabilitation engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
1337511
Ustinova

This proposal requests a Vicon Motion System T160S (Oxford Metrics Ltd) to replace an outdated Qualysis system for motion analysis currently used at Central Michigan University (CMU). The Vicon offers a unique combination of features that will enable cutting-edge research as well as research-based instruction in the area of rehabilitation engineering. The features include: greater camera resolution; wider aperture with greater accuracy of signal processing; minimal latency of real-time feedback; and capabilities for integration with most industrial as well as with custom-made soft- and hardware. The system will serve as a key instrument for establishing a human motion laboratory, currently missing at the university. Establishing the laboratory will expand the opportunities for multi-disciplinary collaboration across disciplines such as engineering and rehabilitation sciences.

por.por_cntn:
The grant sponsored purchase of advanced system for motion analysis, Vicon T160S (Oxford Metrics Ltd). The system became a key element of a newly developed Motion Analysis Center. The center has been used by several multi-disciplinary teams of investigators, who initiated 11 research projects in the area of human movements, with 6 projects completed and the rest being close to completion. The first project investigated effect of wearing compression top on golf swing performance, and showed that wearing the top neither improved nor adversely affected swing performance. This means that the athletic apparel industry could use the results in marketing compression garments, emphasizing that there are no anticipated negative effects on golfers’ performance. The results of the second and third projects revealed significant gait abnormalities in patients after traumatic brain injuries. These individual decompose their leg movements and do not swing arms that significantly affect their walking abilities and require the use of assistive devices. The fourth project validated a custom-made  anipulandum, which was developed to train grasp and grasp release functions in patients with hand impairments after stroke. The results showed that this instrument can facilitate grasp release post stroke, and eventually improve functional abilities of the hand. The instrument will be implemented into post-stroke hand rehabilitation in near future. The fifth project tested different types of industrial tools with the idea of their optimization for the use. The results showed that as hammer mass or handle length is increased the ability to perform work is improved, but this increase potentially comes with the cost of higher loads applied to the human body and increased risk of arm injuries. Considering, that even with industrial automation, hammering is a common manual task some modification of hammer tools may be needed. Finally, the
custom-designed virtual reality games and scenarios were tested and validated in terms of their use for correction of motor coordination problems in individuals with traumatic brain injuries. Based on the results, these
scenarios are being developed now into a product that can be made available either as CD copy or on-line subscription to health care providers and patients.

The newly established Motion Analysis Center has been intensively used for educational purposes. In total, about 240 undergraduate and 100 graduate students used or observed using the motion analysis equipment for 2-4 hours at least, and about 40 graduate students used the equipment for graduate research projects related to human motions. Specifically, the equipment/motion analysis facility were used to cover such topics as: 1) organization and impairments of human gait; 2) assessment of upper and lower extremity movements; 3) kinematics and kinetics of human motions; 4) testing engineering designed equipment for human motions. Students recorded movements, and then were taught how to analyze various movement parameters to qualify and quantify the way human move. All these activities significantly improved teaching of the human motion related discipline in the colleges.
